articles.headline: Biden and Democrats Detail Plans to Raise Taxes on Multinational Firms
articles.snippet: Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen said the U.S. would support a global minimum tax, while top Democrats unveiled their own plan to raise taxes on multinational firms.
articles.abstract: Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen said the U.S. would support a global minimum tax, while top Democrats unveiled their own plan to raise taxes on multinational firms.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Biden administration and top Democrats in Congress began detailing plans for significant changes to how the United States and other countries tax multinational corporations as they look for ways to raise revenues and finance President Biden’s $2 trillion infrastructure proposal.
articles.byline: By Jim Tankersley and Alan Rappeport

articles.headline: ‘The Most Unsafe Workplace’? Parliament, Australian Women Say
articles.snippet: More and more women are describing Parliament House as a sexist backwater. A staff member’s accusation of rape — in a minister’s office, no less — was the catalyst.
articles.abstract: More and more women are describing Parliament House as a sexist backwater. A staff member’s accusation of rape — in a minister’s office, no less — was the catalyst.
articles.lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia — When Julia Banks arrived in Parliament five years ago after a successful career in law and business, she felt as if she’d stepped back into the ’80s. Alcohol flowed freely. She occasionally smelled it on the breath of male lawmakers when they voted.

articles.headline: Biden Plan Spurs Fight Over What ‘Infrastructure’ Really Means
articles.snippet: Republicans say the White House is tucking liberal social programs into legislation that should be focused on roads and bridges. Administration officials say their approach invests in the future.
articles.abstract: Republicans say the White House is tucking liberal social programs into legislation that should be focused on roads and bridges. Administration officials say their approach invests in the future.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The early political and economic debate over President Biden’s $2 trillion American Jobs Plan is being dominated by a philosophical question: What does infrastructure really mean?
articles.byline: By Jim Tankersley and Jeanna Smialek

articles.headline: In Rare Testimony, Chief Says Chauvin ‘Should Have Stopped’ Pinning Floyd
articles.snippet: “To continue to apply that level of force to a person proned out, handcuffed behind their back — that in no way, shape or form is anything that is by policy,” Chief Medaria Arradondo testified.
articles.abstract: “To continue to apply that level of force to a person proned out, handcuffed behind their back — that in no way, shape or form is anything that is by policy,” Chief Medaria Arradondo testified.
articles.lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS — The prospect that a police chief would take the witness stand against a fellow officer is exceedingly rare. But there was the chief of the Minneapolis Police Department on Monday, condemning the actions of Derek Chauvin, the officer charged with murdering George Floyd, as wrong by every imaginable measure.
articles.byline: By Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs, Shaila Dewan and John Eligon

articles.headline: Global Brands Find It Hard to Untangle Themselves From Xinjiang Cotton
articles.snippet: Under pressure to renounce cotton harvested in a Chinese region marked by gruesome repression, they face a backlash from nationalist Chinese consumers.
articles.abstract: Under pressure to renounce cotton harvested in a Chinese region marked by gruesome repression, they face a backlash from nationalist Chinese consumers.
articles.lead_paragraph: Faced with accusations that it was profiting from the forced labor of Uyghur people in the Chinese territory of Xinjiang, the H&M Group — the world’s second-largest clothing retailer — promised last year to stop buying cotton from the region.
articles.byline: By Peter S. Goodman, Vivian Wang and Elizabeth Paton

articles.headline: As China Targets H&M and Nike, Local Brands See Their Chance
articles.snippet: Chinese rivals to Western names have improved quality and marketing. Now the country’s defiance could give them an edge with young patriots.
articles.abstract: Chinese rivals to Western names have improved quality and marketing. Now the country’s defiance could give them an edge with young patriots.
articles.lead_paragraph: Tim Min once drove BMWs. He considered buying a Tesla.

articles.headline: Is Big Business the Democrats’ New Best Friend?
articles.snippet: When C.E.O.s speak out against Republican priorities, it isn’t the flip-flop of alliances it appears to be.
articles.abstract: When C.E.O.s speak out against Republican priorities, it isn’t the flip-flop of alliances it appears to be.
articles.lead_paragraph: “Parts of the private sector keep dabbling in behaving like a woke parallel government.”

articles.headline: Modern Crime-Solving Methods vs. the Mystery of World War II Deaths
articles.snippet: DNA-based techniques that have successfully tracked down elusive serial killers may soon be used to help identify thousands of American service members “known but to God.”
articles.abstract: DNA-based techniques that have successfully tracked down elusive serial killers may soon be used to help identify thousands of American service members “known but to God.”
articles.lead_paragraph: South of Rome, an American military cemetery has a grave that is thought to contain the remains of a young Army private named Melton Futch. But the white marble marker reads only, “Here rests in honored glory a comrade in arms known but to God.”

articles.headline: U.S. Bet Big on Covid Vaccine Manufacturer Even as Problems Mounted
articles.snippet: The Baltimore plant that recently had to scrap up to 15 million ruined doses had flouted rules and downplayed errors, according to internal audits, ex-employees and clients. Other doses had to be scrapped last year.
articles.abstract: The Baltimore plant that recently had to scrap up to 15 million ruined doses had flouted rules and downplayed errors, according to internal audits, ex-employees and clients. Other doses had to be scrapped last year.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — More than eight years ago, the federal government invested in an insurance policy against vaccine shortages during a pandemic. It paid Emergent BioSolutions, a Maryland biotech firm known for producing anthrax vaccines, to have a factory in Baltimore always at the ready.
articles.byline: By Chris Hamby, Sharon LaFraniere and Sheryl Gay Stolberg
